Silk Road School wrote:

> In the Shinto religion, many things are credited with having a spirit and
> the sword is not an exception. However, this was then and now is now.

Actually, this presents a (to me) very interesting point. It's traditional in 
Japan (or at least used to be) for smiths to purify themselves before creating a 
sword, and they had (have?) Shito shrines in their smithies. They even wore the 
traditional priestly white when working.

Yet they were making swords -- the purpose of which was to kill. And death 
(along with blood) are two of the greatest pollutants in Shinto.

To me, that's a very interesting dilemma.

> When
> one picks up a sword of great antiquity and of historical importance, a
> sensitive and sympathetic person cannot help but be greatly impressed. T

Many years ago, I had a koshigatana that had been made in 1368. The mei read 
"Bishu Osafune Munemitsu saku." It was short, very slim (essentially, a katana 
at about 69% scale), with a really deep curve. I loved that sword.

When I went off to Japan in '86, I left it (along with my original ten-volume, 
1700 printing of Arai Hakuseki's "Honcho Gunki-ko") with my old roommates for 
safekeeping. A mutual friend showed up a few weeks later and told them that I'd 
said she could hold on to them for me.

Never saw 'em again.
